messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: This is multiple inheritance, which is typically discouraged in Chrome. Is there a way to factor this such that the handler is a member of the extension?

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> This is multiple inheritance, which is typically discouraged in Chrome. Is there
> a way to factor this such that the handler is a member of the extension?

It's possible, but it would be quite messy. It's probably better to merge ChromeV8ExtensionHandler into ChromeV8Extension, for which I've added a TODO.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text:
On 2012/02/27 01:06:14, koz wrote:
> On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> > This is multiple inheritance, which is typically discouraged in Chrome. Is
> there
> > a way to factor this such that the handler is a member of the extension?
> 
> It's possible, but it would be quite messy. It's probably better to merge
> ChromeV8ExtensionHandler into ChromeV8Extension, for which I've added a TODO.

In that case, I prefer the multiple inheritance.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: The inheritance on v8::Extension no longer makes sense.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: Now that this is no longer inheriting from v8::Extension, it makes even less sense to have the conflicting name. Could we rename it Binding or something?

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: Do we still use the name and dependency params?

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: This might no longer be needed.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: This should not be exposed as interface. It can be in an anonymous namespace in the cc file.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: I think something like AddNativeFunction would be a more clear name. Also the params seem more naturally ordered: object, name, handler.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text:
It would be really nice to avoid this dance in every ChromeV8Extension impl. It should be possible to hold a map of name->member function pointer in the base class. It's kind of a mess of template crap, but the advantage is that subclasses can just say:

Register("foo", &MyClass::DoFoo)

and DoFoo magically gets called.

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> It would be really nice to avoid this dance in every ChromeV8Extension impl. It
> should be possible to hold a map of name->member function pointer in the base
> class. It's kind of a mess of template crap, but the advantage is that
> subclasses can just say:
> 
> Register("foo", &MyClass::DoFoo)
> 
> and DoFoo magically gets called.

The new ModuleSystem handles this.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: There should at least be a TODO to rename this class since it no longer has anything to do with 'handling' chrome v8 extensions. It's just a handy base class for things that want to do routed IPC.

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> There should at least be a TODO to rename this class since it no longer has
> anything to do with 'handling' chrome v8 extensions. It's just a handy base
> class for things that want to do routed IPC.

I've got a TODO to merge this into ChromeV8Extension (and a TODO to rename that class).

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text:
As long as you're changing these files, you might as well just use natives.Foo directly instead of creating this alias. Most of them are only used once.

Also, since we're not using the fancy v8 native function technology anymore, distinguishing these functions specially with a leading capital letter doesn't seem worthwhile. It would look nicer to name them the same as any other function, with camelCase.

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> As long as you're changing these files, you might as well just use natives.Foo
> directly instead of creating this alias. Most of them are only used once.
> 
> Also, since we're not using the fancy v8 native function technology anymore,
> distinguishing these functions specially with a leading capital letter doesn't
> seem worthwhile. It would look nicer to name them the same as any other
> function, with camelCase.

I don't know, I kind of like having the native functions defined up-front. And there's just as much reason to have the names have a leading capital now as there was before - they still denote native functions, they're just set up in different ways.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text:
On 2012/02/27 01:06:14, koz wrote:
> On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> > As long as you're changing these files, you might as well just use natives.Foo
> > directly instead of creating this alias. Most of them are only used once.
> > 
> > Also, since we're not using the fancy v8 native function technology anymore,
> > distinguishing these functions specially with a leading capital letter doesn't
> > seem worthwhile. It would look nicer to name them the same as any other
> > function, with camelCase.
> 
> I don't know, I kind of like having the native functions defined up-front. And
> there's just as much reason to have the names have a leading capital now as
> there was before - they still denote native functions, they're just set up in
> different ways.

OK. Elsewhere in this review, I pointed out unix_hacker names also don't adhere to our js conventions. How do you feel about changing those?

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: Seems like this object should be created in v8_context_. In order to do that you will need to create it in the constructor inside a v8::Context::Scope for v8_context_.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: Use base/memory/linked_ptr instead of doing this manually.

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> Use base/memory/linked_ptr instead of doing this manually.

Done.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text: I'm still not crazy about the magical names. Did you try my suggestion of wrapping in a function?

messages.author: koz
messages.text:
On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> I'm still not crazy about the magical names. Did you try my suggestion of
> wrapping in a function?

No - wrapping it in a function would definitely work, but I think it's just extra boilerplate and an extra source of potential bugs. I think it's okay to have these variables just appear in scope here - almost all JS environments execute JS in a context where extra variables are available (eg: JS on the web, JS in extensions, node) and they wouldn't be improved by requiring developers to enumerate those variables as parameters in an anonymous function.

messages.author: Aaron Boodman
messages.text:
On 2012/02/27 01:06:14, koz wrote:
> On 2012/02/16 01:54:42, Aaron Boodman wrote:
> > I'm still not crazy about the magical names. Did you try my suggestion of
> > wrapping in a function?
> 
> No - wrapping it in a function would definitely work, but I think it's just
> extra boilerplate and an extra source of potential bugs. I think it's okay to
> have these variables just appear in scope here - almost all JS environments
> execute JS in a context where extra variables are available (eg: JS on the web,
> JS in extensions, node) and they wouldn't be improved by requiring developers to
> enumerate those variables as parameters in an anonymous function.

OK, I see your point of view.
